ad for ud
go „ ge
ar „ ar and ur alike ( 1 ) ( 1st and 2nd plural possessive pronoun )
do „ do and de alike ( 1 )
u „ thu ( 2 )
- or „ - mhor , as luthor for luthmhor ( 2 )
na ’ n „ nan , ‘ of the ’
or ’ m „ orm
oir ’ n „ oirnn
air reir „ a ( do ) reir
ma „ mu
mar „ mur
brách „ bràth
cenn „ ceann
tenn „ teann
- amh and - abh „ - aibh ( dative plural )
- is „ - eas ( future relative , active )
- ir „ - ear ( future indicative passive )
- idh „ - eadh ( imperfect )

XXIX . 25 , a black spot ; a blot or blemish .

XI . 38 , a formidable foe . Ir . bíodhbha .

**bliadhna chòrr ,
IX . 25 , a leap year . The reference in MacDonald ’ s glossary is unmistakably to this passage ; but 1746 cannot be made a leap year by any calculation .

XVII . 74 , brigade ; from the English . A . M . V . has braagad , brigade .

caigeann ,

joined , united ; Dw . caigeann ,

Air chairtealabh uainn do ’ n Róimh ;
( 1 )
the expression in all three cases is identical .

càrr ,

VII . 62 , ‘ is a fit of trembling occasioned by eagerness , and being hindered from fighting and revenge . ’

clogaid ,

IX . 60 , XVIII . 42 , XXIX . 20 , v . a . comfort , relieve . ( Dwelly marks obsolete . )

coille ,

III . 35 , XXVIII . 84 , a laurel - tree , a trophy ; here used of a person worthy of the victor ’ s laurel wreath .

crasgach ,
XXVIII . 81 , crossways ; is mairg a thàrladh riu crasgach , pity him who fell foul of them .

IX . 101 , ‘ a eunuch ; also a he sow . ’ Here it is the latter .

dar ,
XXXI . 7 , for
’ n uair ,
when .

X . 32 , XVI . 59 , a blood - brother , a full brother ; Ir . dearbhráthair ; as distinguished from a brother in the sense of a monk or friar .

dos ,

drabasta ,

IV . 14 , see note to same .

Dh ’ ( fh ) idir me bhean bhréun
Na fiordhaithibh pféin ,
( 1 ) etc .
‘ I perceived the vile woman in her own true colours . ’

fiùbhaidh ,
XXXI . 22 , timber , wood . Cf . A . MacDonald , Mi - mholadh Móraig , l . 43 , comparing a woman to a tree of beautiful exterior but inward rottenness : —

Féum d ’ a bun , no bárr ,
Fiui chrìon gun stá
B ’ i an t - olc boigheach i ,
( 2 ) etc .
‘ Never shall carpenter make use of its roots or of its branches , useless brittle wood , a fair , foul thing was she . ’ Ir . fiodhbhadh .

fiùran ,
VII . 89 , a sapling ; hence metaphorically , a blooming or handsome youth .

lòthmhor ,

nì ,

peucach ,
XVII . 15 , peacock - like ; from peucag .

pòr ,
V . 105 , here borrowed from English pore . Cf . ‘ Moladh air píob mhoir Mhic - cruimein , ’
l . 13 - 16 , where MacDonald , speaking of a bagpipe , says : —
Lium a ’ s muirneach ’ n am éri ,
Cruaigh sgal éibhinn do sgórnain ;
Anail - beatha do chréafoig ,
D ’ a séididh roi ’ d ’ phóramh ;
( 1 )
‘ At time of rising I love the joyful shrill cry of thy throat ; the life - breath of thy body blown through thy pores ’ ( i . e . drones ) .
Elsewhere pòr has its usual sense of ‘ seed , race , clan . ’

rabhd ,

sgainnir ,

siomh mar ghad ,

sothadh ,
XII . 11 , turning ; Ir . sódh , act of turning . Occurs as a compound in tionndadh .

spailp ,
XVII . 30 . Cf . Ir . spailp , a turn , a bout ; spailp de ’ n stròic ,
‘ a turn of the stroke , ’ ‘ a considerable journey . ’ Cf . Ir . ag siubhal ar a bhog - stróc , walking slowly or listlessly .

spòltach ,
XXII . 39 , carcase , dead body . Cf . spòlt ,

teamhair ,

tì ,
II . 100 , an tì air ,
determined to , bent on .

tioghaidh ,
XXVI . 94 , Reay dialect for teanga ,

tunnsgal ,
XII . 24 , a form of tionnsgal ,
ingenuity , invention , inventiveness ; luchd tunnsgail ,
fabricators , liars . Cf . Ir . tionnscadal , beginning , projecting , plotting , and tionnsgnadh , above .

ursainn - chatha ,
III . 25 , a champion , literally a ‘ support of battle . ’

ùr - shlat ,
XXXI . 21 , a young sapling .

ùr - thosgair ,
XXXI . 5 , a message , news .
